text: The observed behavior in a blockchain setting are like the transactions that happen on chain.

text: And then you're right that there's so much context that is unobserved in that one data artifact that would be relevant to know about.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And so we can think about two cases where this context is either used or not.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The first case is where we actually have no other context.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: In that situation, we can still do intentional stance modeling towards unknown types of actors.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Like we don't know what is behind this address, but we know that they engage with this kind of a pattern.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And it's not enough just to take a top-down perspective and say, well, this many people interacted with this contract, or the average was two times per day, because that two times per day might be the average of a small fraction that interact 100 times per day and some that interact infrequently.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So cognitive modeling first would help us take an intentional and a strategic stance in the absence of context.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then context, as we add it in,
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: can become useful.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we might know that multiple addresses are under the control of a given team or individual.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Or we might have access to connecting the social media profile of somebody who puts it in their ENS profile or page.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: That could be composable at the agent level and
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I don't think that's an answer at all, so open to whatever else people add, because the miso is where the complexity is, and we would just...
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: expect and prefer that the composability of specifying different kinds of entities, not just on chain entities, but also teams, organizations, and so on, that that will enable these kinds of models to do exploration and parameter sweeps in that exact space you described.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Thank you.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I would maybe also add to that, that as the toolbox itself gets expanded and different computational models are added, I think it's the case where we want to distinguish between an actor that's actually
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: a single human versus a team of people controlling a multisig should technically be reflected in the underlying data to some extent.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Say if, for instance, you want to use cognitive modeling to analyze a certain DAO and you have a list of all the different addresses, as you perform this kind of multi-agent
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: model or even try to fit the belief states of each of the wallets given the prior data, it should become evident that certain wallets perhaps are operating at slightly different timescales or are updating their beliefs at
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: again, at different time scales or in a slightly different way than the other agents.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And then we might also do some cross-correlation between the belief states of the individual actors about which we perhaps know that they are individual actors and the agents that we are not sure whether they represent a single entity or a group of people.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So I think that...
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: A lot of it might already implicitly be available within the current toolbox, but as we add more algorithms that do more efficient computations and different schemes of performing belief updates and belief search, I think that's a very interesting area to explore as well.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Thanks, Jakob.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Brock?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: You want to add anything?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Yeah, I think Jakob's point here about having some verified data sources and having these kinds of generalities about how one kind of data source looks like for one kind of agent versus another kind, more of an organization or
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: a syndicate or some other kind of non-singular individual is correct.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And I think that this idea of the mesoscale being missed, generally speaking, in modeling is also correct.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And I think that cognitive modeling in general affords partially, I guess, a solution to
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: really this mezzo, both of these problems are really related to like the Oracle problem of just where does data come from and who do you trust and all this sort of stuff.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Um, because even if you get this culture data, it's like, you know, what's, what's in the water, what's in the food, what's this business doing with, you know, what are the externalities of this process or whatever?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You know, there's a lot of still unknown data and the only way
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: that we currently have to kind of model that effectively is with essentially a cognitive sort of model that, like you mentioned, Daniel, has this distinction between observed and unobserved or hidden states and known states to the system.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Um, it's never, I guess to frame it, it's, it's like security is this cat and mouse game really we're in this now in this cognitive security cat and mouse game.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we're just going to go further into that, but you know, is a large corporation or whatever, some, some syndicate, whatever, trying to maybe obscure their, you know, um, behavior on chain, like.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: so that they're harder to predict for some reason.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Probably things like that will, they already occur in the political context today.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I'm sure that it will continue and decentralize in that fashion.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so it will just be a baseline, it'll just be table stakes to do cognitive modeling to have any kind of grip
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: on something like prediction or discernibility of these kinds of systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Nice.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Very interesting.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So in the last 10 minutes, we can have any speakers join or people can ask questions.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: This is happening during the ongoing Gitcoin funding round, GR15.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we have a grant in for this project, which is supportable, as well as many other awesome public goods and projects that people can check out.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And on the grant page, you'll see some recent discussions we've had with CADCAD community and with the Smart Contract Research Forum, where we talked about a few different ongoing steps.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The current status of the package is that it's available, it's an open source package, and it is framed as notebooks, primarily made by Jakob, that are like the perception, cognition, and action of an entity in an abstract grid space, which sounds and basically is general and abstract.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So some of our next steps are to bring that machinery and that approach to
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: take in the kinds of empirical data that are relevant for blockchain systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So that's one key area, as well as improving the functionality of the package through various means like improved ability to visualize outcomes of models, to specify models and sweep across them, to have documentation and other integrations that will just make it a better package and more useful.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I guess in the last 10 minutes, there's a few other ways to go, but I'll pause if anyone has any thoughts or questions.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The point I wanted to add in, and then again, anyone can feel free to add, is that
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Using active inference as a scale-free or scale-friendly framework, as we sometimes say, an advantage of it is that we can talk about perception, cognition, and action for different entities.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: This is not creating a little brain for individuals only, people.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: This is about being able to look at how decisions are enacted in different kinds of organizations.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And those organizations could be cellular biological organizations like humans, or it could be organizations that you suspect something complex is happening within, but you're only seeing the tip of the iceberg on-chain.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Or it could be organizations that are entirely on-chain.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And so that's one of the reasons why it's important to have a really flexible modeling framework like Active Inference for cognitive systems, because it's not bound to, for example, only human emotions and sensory processing.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It enables us to describe a wide variety of systems in a cognitive fashion.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: which is what we've explored in our EOS work, Active Entity Ontology for Science.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So that is where we see active inference as a leading cognitive modeling framework and natural fit for this cyber-physical space.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then the other pillar of the active block inference project other than active inference is CAD-CAD, which was mentioned earlier.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And CAD-CAD has been used in a wide range of token modeling and engineering settings.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: You can see actually there
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: ethereum validator models which have been publicly available for uh several years i don't know the exact date but the um work on cad cad modeling of the f proof of stake transition has been in the works for a really long time and that kind of gives a a taste of
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: From the outside, speaking personally, of what it looks like to use formal system models over long timescales to strategize and de-risk really complex decisions that groups and individuals make.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And that is still at the structural level.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So it's one thing to be able to scan across different validator reward systems or percentages and ask what would happen if a certain parameter is set to three or two or one.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Again, it's quite a different thing to ask how entities with different attentions and preferences will make certain decisions.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And so it'd be like the equivalent of a macroeconomic change being induced.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Like we raised the interest rate by 1%.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Our macroeconomic curve intersection models show that that should increase consumer spending by this much.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But that consumer spending, even if it is an accurate prediction from the structural modeling,
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: it is enacted by individuals making decisions in response to those common system parameters so that highlights that the agentic perspective is complementary to the systems and the structural description but we really think that it's going to bring a level of depth
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And also new challenges, because the state space of all cognitive parameters and how they interact is truly vast.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So it will not be necessarily the shortest or simplest road, but we think it's going to be one of the most meaningful because it's going to bring new function to life.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: different Web3 ecosystems and subsystems that otherwise would have totally incommensurate models.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The DeFi models are not going to apply to DAO decision-making, and those are not going to apply to science and how that works.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And having some kind of an interoperable layer for what entities are doing what is going to be
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: enabling really rich modeling of Web3 ecosystems.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Now, can Web3 survive without cognitive modeling?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I don't know.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We could vote.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But we provocatively raised the question.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I think Jakob and Brock and others in some meetings with this framing, because we do want to suggest or at least raise this notion that no amount of top level systems engineering
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: unless it's complemented by a bottom-up perspective on what are the capacities, attentions, preferences, and so on of entities in this world.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The embodied natural ones, as well as computational artifacts, a runaway decision-making AI with a trading balance, all these kinds of systems that we have to model, including systems that we don't even know what type they are necessarily,
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We need interoperable and expressive ways to describe those systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So that's why we think that Web3 with cognitive modeling can survive and without, we just don't know.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I have another question.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I think it relates fundamentally to potential biases in a model given
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: data availability.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So it's very clear always what data is available, like what transactions are on chain or what prices are paid in market for securities or commodity or what have you.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But there is actually a lot that occurs in society, which is not necessarily a market type
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: activity with hard data associated with it.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And how does a cognitive model account for the fact that many things are missed and that we simply overlook many aspects of things that, for instance, might be called the gift economy, where people just informally do things for each other and it's
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: not really recorded anywhere.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I mean, it is truly part of the representation of our individual cognitive models for how we exist in the world.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But where is this going to make it into any model that we try to do?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's great.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: question, and it's a thread I hope we keep alive even beyond this space ending in a few minutes.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So no answer will do it justice, but I'll give some thoughts.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: One is the difference between observables in our model, empirical data that we're reading in, and unobservables, which are considered factors, but not necessarily ones where we have data points, either because we just haven't added those data points in or maybe they don't even exist in principle.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So various kinds of features can be observed
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: and various can't be.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So it's important to have a framework that deals with both.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then the second point is that it may be possible for some kind of like out in the open models to use some kinds of totally out in the open data.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But then let's just say that within the context of a given community of care, people consented to having their information
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: digested or summarized, and used to augment a community-specific model.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So the provenance and the use of that data that would be potentially speaking to these more authentic, inorganic social interactions, those kinds of data could be grafted or fused with more open-source templates dealing with open data.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So there'd be a lot of opportunity for model templates and some pre-computed public goods type data sets to then be enriched on the edges by different communities that were going to be bringing in specific data types.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And the path has been in a way blazed forward by CAD-CAD where the package is open source and many of their models are open source yet
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: They're also able to engage with clients in a consulting capacity using models that are not fully open source, probably, or data sets that aren't fully available.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So it's one reason why we are strongly open source with the package, while also recognizing that a lot of the last mile use cases might bring in data that isn't strictly open source in the same way that this code should be.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Okay.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Well, thanks for listening, everyone.
